head.title: Deep in Those Campaign Ads, an Important Message

hedline.hl1: Deep in Those Campaign Ads, an Important Message

abstract.p: Letter from Sarah Weddington, lawyer who represented Jane Roe in Roe v Wade, comments on May 25 critique of political ads and impact of presidential election on Supreme Court

block.p: A chart accompanying ''Campaign Ads Are Under Fire for Inaccuracy'' (front page, May 25) spotlights Senator John Kerry's campaign advertisement that says the Supreme Court is one vote away from overturning the landmark Supreme Court case Roe v. Wade.

A chart accompanying ''Campaign Ads Are Under Fire for Inaccuracy'' (front page, May 25) spotlights Senator John Kerry's campaign advertisement that says the Supreme Court is one vote away from overturning the landmark Supreme Court case Roe v. Wade.

We now know from the papers of Justice Harry A. Blackmun, the author of the Roe decision, that a Supreme Court majority would have voted to overturn Roe in 1992. Only the switch of Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's vote saved Roe.

During his administration, President Clinton made more favorable appointments. Nevertheless, the most recent Supreme Court abortion ruling came down to a 5-to-4 vote. A central disagreement between the majority and the dissent was over a core principle enunciated in Roe: states may not impose restrictions on abortion that would threaten a woman's health. The majority upheld that principle -- but by only a single vote.

The exact issue the Supreme Court will decide next is uncertain. But who serves on that Supreme Court is of critical importance. Your critique missed the point of the ad, which was to remind voters of the importance of the next president's role in naming new justices to the court.
The writer represented ''Jane Roe'' before the Supreme Court in Roe v. Wade.
